words.definition: A stylesheet language used to describe the presentation and formatting of HTML or XML documents on the web.
words.example: CSS controls the colors, fonts, and layout of a website.
examples: CSS makes web pages visually appealing.

words.definition: A file or block of code containing CSS rules that define the appearance of web content.
words.example: Link an external stylesheet to style your site.
examples: Stylesheets separate content from presentation.
words.notes: Can be external, internal, or inline.[1][2][4][5][7]

words.definition: A pattern in CSS that targets specific HTML elements to apply styles.
words.example: The .alert selector targets elements with class='alert'.
examples: Selectors can be tags, classes, ids, or attributes.
words.notes: Selectors determine which elements are styled.[1][3][4][6][7]

words.definition: A statement in CSS consisting of a selector and a declaration block that applies styles to elements.
words.example: The rule p { color: blue; } makes all paragraphs blue.
examples: Rules are the building blocks of CSS.

words.definition: A part of a CSS rule that specifies a property and its value, such as color: red;.
words.example: The declaration font-size: 16px; sets text size.
examples: Declarations are inside curly braces after a selector.
words.notes: Multiple declarations can be in one rule.[1][3][4][6][7]

words.definition: The aspect of an element to be styled, such as color, font-size, or margin.
words.example: The color property sets text color.
examples: Properties are followed by a colon and value.

words.definition: The setting assigned to a CSS property, such as red, 16px, or flex.
words.example: The value bold makes text bold.
examples: Values can be colors, sizes, or keywords.

words.definition: Describes how CSS applies multiple rules to the same element, combining and overriding styles based on specificity and order.
words.example: Cascading allows flexible, layered styling.
examples: The cascade resolves conflicts between rules.
words.notes: Name comes from the cascade of rules.[1][2][3][4][5][6][7][8]

words.definition: A ranking system that determines which CSS rule applies when multiple rules target the same element.
words.example: ID selectors have higher specificity than class selectors.
examples: Specificity resolves conflicts between rules.

words.definition: The mechanism by which some CSS property values are passed from parent elements to their children.
words.example: Font family is often inherited by child elements.
examples: Inheritance simplifies consistent styling.

words.definition: A CSS style applied directly to an HTML element using the style attribute.
examples: Inline styles override external and internal styles.

words.definition: A separate .css file linked to an HTML document, containing CSS rules for the site.
words.example: <link rel="stylesheet" href="styles.css">
examples: External stylesheets enable global styling.

words.definition: A block of CSS rules placed inside a <style> tag in the HTML document's <head>.
words.example: <style>p { color: blue; }</style>
examples: Internal stylesheets affect only the current page.
words.notes: Scoped to a single HTML file.[1][2][3][4][5][6][7]

words.definition: A group of declarations enclosed in curly braces after a selector in a CSS rule.
words.example: The block in h1 { color: red; } sets the style.
examples: Blocks contain one or more declarations.
words.notes: Blocks are always inside curly braces.[1][3][4][6][7]

words.definition: A note in CSS code for developers, ignored by browsers, written as /* comment */.
words.example: /* This is a CSS comment */
examples: Comments help document CSS code.
words.notes: Block comments only; no inline // comments.[1][3][4][5][6][7]

words.definition: A CSS technique for applying styles based on device characteristics like screen width or orientation.
words.example: @media (max-width: 600px) { ... }
examples: Media queries enable responsive design.

words.definition: Describes web design that adapts to different screen sizes and devices using CSS.
words.example: Responsive layouts look good on all devices.
examples: Responsive design uses media queries and flexible units.

words.definition: The CSS concept that every element is a rectangular box consisting of content, padding, border, and margin.
words.example: The box model explains element sizing and spacing.
examples: Box model is key to layout and alignment.

words.definition: An HTML element that starts on a new line and stretches out to the left and right as far as it can, forming a block box in CSS.
words.example: <div> is a block element.
examples:
Block elements include

,

,
    ,
    .
words.notes: Block elements respect width, height, margin, and padding.[1][4][5]

words.definition: An HTML element that does not start on a new line and only takes up as much width as necessary, forming an inline box in CSS.
words.example: <span> is an inline element.
examples: Inline elements include <a>, <em>, <strong>, <span>.
words.notes: Inline elements ignore width and height properties.[1][4][5]

words.definition: A CSS property that specifies how an element is displayed on the page, such as block, inline, flex, or grid.
words.example: display: flex; creates a flex container.
examples: Change display to switch between block and inline.

words.definition: A CSS property that defines how the width and height of an element are calculated: either including (border-box) or excluding (content-box) padding and borders.
words.example: box-sizing: border-box; includes padding and border in width.
examples: box-sizing: content-box; is the default.

words.definition: The innermost area of the CSS box model, containing the actual content of the element.
words.example: Width and height apply to the content box by default.
examples: Padding and border are outside the content box.

words.definition: The area in the CSS box model that includes the content and padding, but not the border or margin.
words.example: Padding box expands the content area.
examples: Padding adds space inside the border.

words.definition: The area in the CSS box model that includes the content, padding, and border, but not the margin.
words.example: border-box includes border and padding in width.
examples: box-sizing: border-box; changes sizing behavior.
words.notes: Border is visible around content and padding.[1][2][3][5][7]

words.definition: The outermost area of the CSS box model, including the content, padding, border, and margin.
words.example: Margin box defines space between elements.
examples: Margins are always transparent.
words.notes: Margins separate boxes from each other.[1][2][3][5][7]

words.definition: The default layout mode in CSS, where elements are placed on the page in the order they appear in the HTML.
words.example: Block elements stack vertically in normal flow.
examples: Normal flow is altered by float, position, or flex.
words.notes: Basis for all CSS layout models.[1][4][5][7]

words.definition: A CSS property that removes an element from normal flow and positions it to the left or right, allowing text and inline elements to wrap around it.
words.example: float: left; aligns an element to the left.
examples: Floats are used for images and sidebars.
words.notes: Floats are less common in modern layouts.[1][4][5][7]

words.definition: A CSS property that controls the behavior of elements following floated elements, preventing them from wrapping around the float.
words.example: clear: both; moves an element below any floated elements.
examples: Clear is used to fix float-related layout issues.

words.definition: A CSS property that specifies how an element is positioned in the document: static, relative, absolute, fixed, or sticky.
words.example: position: absolute; removes the element from normal flow.
examples: Position controls advanced layouts and overlays.

words.definition: A CSS property that controls the stacking order of positioned elements along the z-axis.
words.example: z-index: 10; brings an element to the front.
examples: z-index only works on positioned elements.
words.notes: Higher z-index is rendered on top.[1][4][5][7]

words.definition: A three-dimensional conceptual layer in CSS that controls the stacking order of elements along the z-axis.
words.example: A new stacking context is created by position or opacity.
examples: Stacking contexts isolate z-index calculations.

words.definition: A CSS property that controls what happens when content overflows an element's box, such as scroll, hidden, or auto.
words.example: overflow: auto; enables scrollbars when needed.
examples: Overflow can hide or reveal extra content.

words.definition: A CSS layout model that provides an efficient way to align and distribute space among items in a container.
words.example: display: flex; enables flexbox layout.
examples: Flexbox simplifies vertical and horizontal alignment.

words.definition: A CSS layout system that allows for two-dimensional layouts using rows and columns.
words.example: display: grid; enables grid layout.
examples: Grid is ideal for complex page structures.

words.definition: A CSS property that sets the spacing between items in a flex or grid container.
words.example: gap: 16px; adds space between grid items.
examples: Gap works with flexbox and grid layouts.
